DOC.HEAD: Big Chill Boosts California Winter Tourist Season
DOC.TEXT: December's record deep freeze has Easterners and Midwesterners clogging phone lines at desert resorts and Universal Studios as they seek escape in the Southern California sun. ``We have an 800 number to call for information about Palm Springs and it's been ringing off the hook. And most of the calls have been from back East,'' said Carolyn Patten of the Palm Springs city tourism office. ``They want to know `Can we get some sun?' They are so tired of the snow. I don't know how they're going to feel in March, but they hate it now,'' Patten said Thursday. It's too early to cite statistics, but a survey of resort hotels in the Coachella Valley surrounding Palm Springs indicated this winter tourist season looks like a scorcher, with a hot streak of early bookings. ``The phones are just going crazy on us,'' said Jim Lopez, marketing director at the 860-room Marriott Desert Springs Resort in Palm Desert. ``We've seen an increase in reservations within a two-week time period, and I think that's because it's been pretty darn cold around the country.'' Typical high temperatures last weekend were 12 in Detroit, 14 in Indianapolis, 44 in Miami Beach and 37 in Orlando, Fla. It was 82 in Palm Springs, part of unseasonably warm weather in what forecasters say may be the driest December since 1876. Since then, things have averaged out again, with temperatures in both Florida and Southern California running in the 60s and 70s. But the earlier news of the big chill that extended into Florida had its effect. ``Some of the people coming from back East this year have remarked they were coming here instead of Florida because the weather is better,'' said Ken Irwin at La Mancha Private Villas, where amenities such as private swimming pools and tennis courts come at a price tag of up to $895 a night. Overall, Southern California tourism has been slowing despite an increase in foreign visitors, said Jack Kyser, chief economist for the Greater Los Angeles Chamber of Commerce. Americans are traveling less because of fears of a weaker economy, higher air fares ``and there is a lingering fear of earthquakes,'' Kyser said. But at the Universal Studios tour, where a fake quake is a popular ride, the flood of calls has been greater than usual this post-Christmas season, said spokesman Jim Yeager. ``The tour guide person says the last two to three days the line has been ringing off the hook with people from the East Coast,'' Yeager said. ``We are getting a lot of calls coming in and the first question asked is, `What is the weather?''' said Rolfe G. Arnhym, executive vice president of the Palm Springs Chamber of Commerce. All that interest could disappear, he points out, with just one cold snap or a few stories about desert storms. ``We've had situations where the weather has done a 180 on us and our tourists have scampered off elsewhere.''
